## Load Packages

We first loading the R packages needed for text-mining, data manipulation, and visualization. 

```{r}
library(tidyverse) 
library(tidytext)
library(wordcloud)
```

## Import Data

We now import the dataset from I-Analyzer into an R dataframe called `data_df`. We also convert the dates in the `date-pub` from string format to one that is suited for analysis in R. 

```{r}
data_file_name <- '../data/data.csv'

data_df <- read_delim(data_file_name, 
    delim = ";", 
    escape_double = FALSE, 
    col_types = cols(`date-pub` = col_date(format = "%B %d, %Y"), 
        issue = col_integer()), trim_ws = TRUE)
```

## Tokenizing Raw Data Into Words

Here we tokenize the raw data in `data_df` into a new dataframe called `tidy_content`. Tokenizing means that we split the content into single words.

```{r}
tidy_content <- data_df %>% unnest_tokens(word, content, token="words")
```

## Data Cleaning

The following code block helps us clean data, by removing NA values in the issue column.

```{r}
tidy_content <- tidy_content[!is.na(tidy_content$issue), ]
```

Next, we import the stop words into our environment. The stop words are provided with the `tidytext` package.

We continue the data cleaning, by removing the stop words from the `tidy_content` dataframe and creating a new dataframe called `tidy_clean_content` based on that. 

```{r, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
data(stop_words)

tidy_clean_content <- tidy_content %>% anti_join(stop_words)
```
